Half-Life: Blue Shift is the shortest of the two expansions for Half-Life that provides the back story of Barney Calhoun as he fights to escape Black Mesa with other science personnel.  Players may recall Barney's role in Half-Life 2 and in the case of Blue Shift, it felt nice to view the events of Half-Life through a different lense, just as in Oposing Force.  That being said, the game is indeed short and does not really introduce anything new in terms of weapons or gameplay compared to Half-Life.  The only major gameplay difference is that Barney cannot use the H.E.V. charging stations and instead must collect armor vests and helmets (actually a nice throwback to older shooters).  You'll go back to Xen for a short mission but most of the time you will be working your way through Black Mesa resuing scientists.  There are a few nods to other games in the Half-Life timeline too scattered throughout Barney's journey.  For the price and length of the game, I'd recommend getting this on a sale if you enjoyed Half-Life and want more lore.

Half-Life Blue Shift is a fun game. It does have problems though. Compared to Half-Life 1 and Opposing Force, this is the least good out of the three. It didn't introduce any new enemies or guns. It also didn't really have any awesome boss fights like the other two before it. The storyline isn't nearly as in depth or good as HL1 or OF. The game is SIGNIFICANTLY shorter than HL1 and OF. Nothing really new came out of the game. I feel that the makers of the game could've done a way better job. However, since I am a big Half-Life fan, I do think this game is fun to play. There are moments where the combat is intense. I would say it's a nice little game to play and finish in one weekend. It was worth the 99 cents I payed in the summer sale. If you're a Half-Life fan, you at least owe it to yourself and the series to pick up the game and play it.

The second “interquel” to Half-Life is lived through the eyes of Barney Calhoun, a security officer at Black Mesa, that is seen by Gordon Freeman at the very beginning of the game. This game also takes place at the same time as Half-Life, but starts before the incident and is chronologically placed prior to Opposing Force. Barney’s journey through Black Mesa isn’t an easy one, but surely it is a short one, as Blue Shift is even shorter than Opposing Force. Also, the game doesn’t add any major improvements over other games in the series, and is thus to be considered just another expansion of the story. A really nice one at that, at it deserves a playthrough for sure, but the story will be over very soon. Unfortunately.

Short and kinda unimaginative compared to Opposing Force. My biggest issue is some of the puzzles are far-fetched and too subtle, like when you need to find that ladder hidden behind a pipe facing a dead end. But hey, it's still Half-Life!

It's an expansion for Half-Life where you play a different character, with a slight emphasis on platform puzzles and dark areas. 

Although it came out afterwards, since it's short and actually ends in the middle of the main game's story, I recommend playing Blue Shift first before Opposing Force. Not a lot of unique mechanics, but still offers the same old good stuff. 

Is it worth your time? If you like Half-Life, yeah, it definitely is.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is similar to the episodic expansions for Half-Life 2, but in this case it Blue Shift expands of the world of the first Half-Life. Blue Shift has you play as Barney Calhoun, a security gaurd at Black Mesa who gets caught up in the events of the resonance cascade. The objective is the same as in the Half-Life main game, and that is to escape the horrible mess that you are entangled in. The graphics of the game are dated, but are not hard to look at, in fact I would say they give the game a charm to it. The game plays identically to the original Half-Life with no real new gameplay changes; same weapons, and same enemies. There are however a few new textures and characters that are part of the overarching Half-Life story. Blue Shift is an overall great experience that is a must have if you are trying to learn everything about the Half-Life universe.

It isn't the old graphics or the bad writing that really bothers me, it's the sloppy controls, bad puzzle elements and dumb platforming that really does it in for me. Blue Shift isn't something I want to play.

A very short but scintillating expansion. I honestly don't know or don't care why the reviewers scolded this little, innocent expansion so much. It shows us that cute Barney is also a murdering machine which is great I say. The game introduced the Half-Life HD pack. It also has some pretty original puzzles, making the copy-paste Half-Life gameplay a little more sufferable, for the third time in a row. It can't compare with Opposing Force with originality though. It doesn't add new weapons, but it is as full of details as the previous two games. It also has a happy ending, without you being obligatorily captured by G-Man. It features a great character named Dr Rosenberg that you will interact with and help him escape Black Mesa. Oh and you can see Gordon Freeman himself at least 3 times during the play. It's a must for any Half-Life fan, even though it's that short and not extremely inventive, gameplay and story-wise.
It's a fun expansion pack to the original Half-Life game, sharing the gameplay style and features of the original.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is the second expansion pack to the original Half-Life. Much like Opposing Force, you play from the point of view of a Black Mesa security guard named Barney Calhoun. Once again, the events in this game run parallel to the original so it's fun to see Gordon Freeman around. This expansion is the much shorter than Opposing Force, however it's still fun even though there are no new weapons or enemies introduced. For Half-Life fans this expansion is great in offering more gameplay and rounding up the Half-Life 1 storyline.

"Half Life: Blue Shift" ist ein allein lauffähiges Add-On zum legendären First-Person-Shooter, das im Jahre 2001, also etwa drei Jahre nach dem Hauptspiel, auf den Markt kam.

Erinnerst Du Dich noch an die Anfangssequenz von "Half-Life"? Als Gordon Freeman trug Dich eine Schwebebahn durch den riesiegen unterirdischen Forschungskomplex Black Mesa. und an einer Stelle, ganz am Anfang, nur kurz, fuhrst Du an einem Wachmann vorbei, der gegen eine Tür klopfte, die offenbar eine Störung im Öffnungsmechanismus hatte. Du weißt es nicht, aber dieser Wachmann war Barney Calhoun und wird der Protagonist von "Blue Shift" sein.

Ein einfacher Wachmann also, kein Superheld. Die Introsequenz beginnt ähnlich wie im Original mit einer Schwebebahnfahrt zu eben jener Tür. Diese wird erst geöffnet, nachdem wir Gordon Freeman an uns vorbeifahren gesehen haben. Wir rüsten uns aus, mit einer Pistole, Schutzweste und Helm und sollen einen steckengebliebenen Aufzug kontrollieren. Da nehmen die Dinge ihren Lauf, Explosionen, Feuer, Tote. Außerirdische Lebensformen dringen durch ein Portal, das aus Versehen geöffnet wurde in unsere Welt und greifen alles an, was ihnen über den Weg läuft. Unsere wichtigste Aufgabe: Black Mesa möglichst lebend zu verlassen.

Technisch ist Vergleich zum Hauptspiel wenig passiert, lediglich ein paar Texturen wurden verbessert. Auch akustisch hat sich nicht viel getan. Die Shooter-Mechaniken funktionieren aber nach wie vor hervorragend.
 
"Blue-Shift" ist mit 3-4 Stunden Spielzeit erstaunlich kurz und im Vergleich zum Hauptspiel erstaunlich eintönig. Dabei ist das Leveldesign nach wie vor exzellent. Gegnerpassagen wechseln sich mit kleinen Jump- und Schalterpassagen ab. Aber die Entscheidung einen simplen Wachmann zu spielen, hat einige Einschränkungen zur Folge. Wir tragen keinen Power-Suit, sondern nur eine Schutzweste, können uns also auch nicht an HEV-Stationen aufladen. Trotzdem Teile von "Blue Shift" auch auf der Alien-Welt spielen, bleibt unser Waffenarsenal im Vergleich erstaunlich erdgebundene Standardkost. 

"Blue Shift" macht ohne Frage Spaß, man kann sich aber nicht dem Eindruck erwehren, daß bei weitem nicht das Potential ausgeschöpft wurde.

Half Life: Life Blue Shift is one of the two standalone expansion packs for the original Half-Life. Developed by Gearbox and overseen by Valve. Blue Shift is definitely weaker than Opposing Force in terms of pretty much everything. That does not mean it is bad, the game just refuses to take risks or add anything new. You play as Black Mesa security officer Barney Calhoun, who is in the middle of his shift when the Resonance Cascade happens, he then has to find a way to escape Black Mesa. The gameplay is the same as the original Half-Life, but with no fun new enemies or weapons like in Opposing Force. But I still recommend the game because it reveals more of the story of Half-Life, and it is always fun to see a game's story line from a different perspective.
TLDR: The weaker of the two expansions for Half-Life because it does not take risks or attempt anything new. Still keeps the fun gameplay, and it is cool to see the Black Mesa Incident from a different perspective.

Tym razem wcielamy się w postać jednego ze strażników kompleksu, odzianego w zgrabny niebieski mundurek (stąd nazwa dodatku) Barneya Calhouna. Mimo tego, że gra nie poraża długością (całość da się skończyć w niespełna cztery godziny) i nie jest tak złożona jak Opposing Force - warto ją zaliczyć, bo zgrabnie domyka całą, "jedynkową" trylogię.

[H1] Half Life: Blue Shift [/h1]

What is it?

Blue shift is a standalone mod for Half life 1, or the gold source engine so to speak, that is based around the original half life series. During the game, you play as a security guard, working yet another day at black mesa. But this day is'nt the same as any other. Scientists find a way to another dimension, and where are you when it all happens? In the elevator, like a chum.

All of the aspects of Half life, thrown into a smaller and shorter story. 

[b] I loved it [/b]

It may be short, but there are a few puzzles that make you run around a bit, even though the answer was right in front of your face the entire time. Alteast that was the case for me. As I played, I made my own way of what weapons to use against what enemies. How to take them down and so forth. If you know how to B-Hop, then the movement will go a lot quicker. If you dont? Get a script, it will really help with the movement in this game. It honestly would have taken me an extra half hour not b-hopping to finish it.

But in all reality, a very good classic. Glad I bought it again on steam. Played the mod when it came out, and now I have the memory attatched forever.

Thanks a lot Valve

Ps: I could tottally get a refund for this game, and then get opposing force instead. 2 for 1 really. But I support you, so I will buy Opposing force and play that too!
